text:
Am I the only person on earth that thinks being famous would be a nightmare? I understand wanting more money but being rich is a separate thing.  I'm talking about just the fame part because you can be rich anonymously...

I would hate the whole world judging me, knowing all of my business, making up lies about me, making fun of me. I feel like it would be so awkward to meet new people..  do they know who I am? If not I might feel dumb, especially meeting other celebs wondering if they know me, lol. I would hate the paparazzi on my lawn, not knowing if my friends are using me, no privacy, I would hate reading a bunch of mean comments from the jerks of life that are miserable with themselves and so they hate anyone successful. I'd hate having to go online and being tempted to do a Google search on myself... 

I would hate the pressure of looking perfect, of signing autographs and constantly having to say no to people when they want something... I'd hate the way the public turns on you if you make one mistake, how most people are fair weather friends  (and fans) and let the media brainwash them into thinking the celeb is bad. I'd hate how if you get one bad review your career can be finished. Ugh...

I could go on forever on why I would hate fame . Sure you get some praise and fans but it seems like we humans are wired to focus on the bad.  A bunch of celebrities hate being famous once they achieve it and you can't really ever get your anonymity back. That's why so many have drug problems... Harrison Ford said that the only good thing about fame is getting a good table at a restaurant and that he'd rather be a regular person. I think it would feel like I always had to be "on", like you are working a job 24/7.

 You can still put music out or write books and keep your anonymity so I don't understand why everybody wants fame.  Even if I was an actor I'd only act in local plays, lol. Am I alone in thinking fame would be a nightmare?

text:
@Osama Bin Laden .... I'm Australian.

This "homophobic majority" are also old, poor, and raised in an environment that dictates their way of thinking. When you look at the demographics of it, the most homophobic countries are impoverished and have a backwards government. So, your country, probably.

Homophobes may be the majority, but they're not advancing in society. In fact, they're declining. See, the most homophobic age group is the elderly while the most accepting age group is the young and middle-aged. You're a bit behind with your "way of thinking"... The most accepting countries of homosexuality are Scandinavian and European -- the most forward thinking, progressive and successful countries in the world. African and Asian countries are also the most homophobic, and look at how they're going... Not great.

So sorry if your "way of thinking" is what you've been raised with, if it's what you've been taught, if it's what you believe in or if it's simply tradition, but homophobia won't be the majority and while we progress with a more accepting society, you'll still be a third world country.

@Khechari Yes, people do get brutally killed in a lot of horror movies, but most of the times there are some that make it out alive and defeat the killer/ghosts/whatever. I'm talking about the ending, don't you understand? As TheAllKnowingTribute said, a classic example is the Scream series. The final girl, Sidney Prescott, survives Scream 1, then in 2 she is more grown-up and the events changed her, but after the second massacre, part 3 shows her being completely scared for her life and hiding from even her friends. However, in the grand finale, she becomes strong and fights for her life and wins. And in Scream 4, which takes place 10 years after 3, she is now a strong woman, and a true survivor. And she is no longer scared to confront the killer(s).
See? Isn't that nice? :]

text: @spearofconquest Celebrities or not I will never be okay with people showing hatred to one another. Did you ever think that maybe these celebrities agreed to do this to show people that they need to think before they act. author: Lupita V.

text: @Lupita V. Did you come to this video purely to type this?
author: Metalchick721

text: @Metalchick721 No, it was a suggested video for a Jimmy Fallon video I was watching and when I saw the title of the video I immediately wanted to know if this video really helped the commentators that are on YouTube think about how hate comments on YouTube can effect people. Of course not all saw it the way I did and that's why I typed this.
author: Lupita V.

text: @Lupita V. I stand by my first statement. When it comes to comedy, either everything is sacred or nothing is.
author: Metalchick721

text: @Metalchick721 Sorry but I don't see you're first comment unless you're referring to the question you asked me. Its a probability Jimmy Kimmel did put this comedy section to get some laughs but all the famous people you see on here can do other things than read hate comments about them for money. So personally, I can't help but think that if they agreed to do this, its either to show people that they don't care what people say or to get people to think about what they say before they say it. I've seen comedians say inappropriate stuff and that's fine if you find that kind of stuff funny but I won't laugh at another persons expense. That's just my decision though and I will preach against hate anytime I see it.
author: Lupita V.

text: @Lupita V. Almost all comedy is at others' expense. Jesus, you sound so pretentious.
author: Metalchick721

text: @Metalchick721 Jesus has nothing to do with it. Just because many people do something does it make it right. I don't care about impressing other and i'm sorry if I come off that way. I just do and say what I feel is the right thing is no matter what others think of me.
author: Lupita V.

text: @Lupita V. Wow you sound so pretentious.
author: Metalchick721

text: @Metalchick721 I know you already said that. Anything else?
author: Lupita V.

text: @Lupita V. As in nobody listens to people who speak as though they are above them, regardless of the validity of their point.
author: Metalchick721

text: @Metalchick721 "People" or you? Regardless of what you or anybody else thinks of me, I'm still going to comment whether you want me to or not. Pretentious means coming off as trying to impress people. The word your thinking of is cocky. You can think what you want of me The Lord knows I can't control that but I know i'm just confident in who I am and I don't need to prove that to anybody especially not to someone who tries to attack me personally because their argument failed.  Despite your insults, I have nothing against you personally.
author: Lupita V.

text: @Lupita V. You say you're not trying to prove something and yet you keep going. Your general speech has a "Holier-than-thou" feel to it, and no most people don't want to listen to someone who speaks as though they are above them.
author: Metalchick721

text: @Metalchick721 Yeah I keep going because I believe in what I say.  I don't want people to not think about what they say before they do it because one person doesn't think its a big deal. Its only not a big deal to you because nobody's directing any hate comments at you. Doesn't matter how you say it, like I said before people can think what they want of me its really none of my business what they think. However, if even one person looks at the comment that I made and  they start considering what I said than it was well worth it. I'm not arguing for the looks and that's the truth you can believe what you want. In fact, i'm not even sure if anybody else is actually reading our comments when there's tons of other comments on this video and it would be pretty egotistical for me to presume they are. If you haven't noticed you keep arguing as well and I get it. We live in a society where everyone wants the last word. I'll be honest, so do I. I'm willing to put my pride aside and I won't respond to anything else you say because i'm capable of change.
author: Lupita V.

text: @Lupita V.  I think it's more of how silly the people tweeting them are and how they are the joke and not the celebrities I mean honestly the can't let maybe...20 percent of the world bothered them cause 80 percent loves them and finds them amazing.

text: @Randall Goguen yeah you did and you tagged me. And you said "your really going to hate this"  when people say that it's because another person said they hated something or someone. text:
Δημοσιεύτηκε στις 22 Μαΐ 2014
There are a lot of celebrities on twitter and some people feel very comfortable using twitter to insult those celebrities. From time to time, we gather those insults and package them together to illustrate the fact that words can hurt. This is our 7th edition of Mean Tweets featuring Julia Roberts, Don Cheadle, Ashton Kutcher, Courteney Cox, Andy Garcia, Mindy Kaling, David Blaine, Don Rickles, Ethan Hawke, Matthew McConaughey, June Squibb, Jeremy Piven, Kit Harrington, Emma Stone, Gary Oldman and Sofia Vergara.

text:
When people write stuff on the internet, even more if it's about celebrities, they lose all sense of empathy. That's why people insult each other and cyber-bully : you don't feel the pain you're causing. You don't have to look at your victim's reaction, so you deshumanize and objectify them. 
With these videos, yes, viewers come here by voyeurism. But they still get to realize what they write and what it does to a person.
(p.s.- If you don't think that it's needed, just take a look at the previous replies on this comment... all the examples needed are here)

text: I don't think it's as clear as us sharing in on the insult. In fact, I respect a lot of these celebrities and when I hear these things I'm actually flabbergasted that there are people out there that dislike them so much. In a way, it shows that we're all more alike than we think - there will be ppl who won't like us even when we're good, and the person writing them might not be right anyway. It just shows how varied opinions can be. This discussion is a testament to that. I understand that some of the celebs look hurt, and that makes me sad, but by watching, I feel for them and want to help them up. So the insult can have an opposite effect, and I wouldn't be surprised if that's the reason for this segment - most of the insults are absurd which diminishes the comment as a result!

Besides I think you work on your capitals at the start of a phrase or punctuation at the end of a phrase. Even you should get the difference of "it's or its". Really, and you're judging me ? Y'know instead of judging others, perhaps you should work on your own mistakes firsts, than you can have rights to say anything you want. But so far, you just made a fool of yourself.
author: Alexandru DG

text:
@Madara Uchiha I'm far from a child, I dont care all that much about punctuation in peoples comments, its just that i've never seen that particular one used, must be an american thing perhaps? however you're right it is commonly used however I'm also right..

"The use of 'n for "and" or "ing" is of course totally different from writing still kickin', which seems to me more closely follows the rule of abbreviations that the apostrophe takes the place of the dropped letter(s), as with "Oh no you didn't!". A Google search for "rock n roll" turned up rock 'n' roll (the way I have written it in the past, following the rule), rock-n-roll, Rock"N"Roll, Rock'n'Roll, as well as rock 'n roll"

however that was from a blog.. so not the most reliable source admittedly.   
I didn't intend on having a long back and forth about it,
author: Smdylan

text:
@Smdylan Yes it can be used differently, but in my concept, you are wrong about "freak'n" because if you use common knowledge and logic, you would know that in the concept I used, it would be "freaking brains" not "freak and brains". Like if you use the knowledge said in that blog, you could easily figure out when "and" or "ing" is used. 
If you try it out on my concept, you would know it's "ing" not "and". But if you try it on "rock and roll" you would know it's "and" not "ing". Get the point ? So if you say it should be "and" in my concept, it would be wrong. It's the same thing when you need to figure out when you use "it is" or "its".

text: @Cam Maida lots of things are possible, but everything we observe about the universe from here tells us that the rules of the universe are the same everywhere. That things can't go from point A to point B without actually traveling between those points. That energy spreads out and weakens as it spreads out. That things are either in one place or they are spread out. All the things people like to believe about the gods that we have invented here on earth are just fantasies. When we were children, we all imagined things like flying, or teleportation, or wishes that could come true. But when you grow up, you're supposed to forget about things like that and learn to live in reality and accept things the way they are. Anything is possible, but the stories that people told themselves thousands of years ago about powerful beings that lived in the sky or at the top of the mountain or wherever are clearly just that: stories. Jehovah is no more likely to be true then is Thor or Zeus or Osiris or any other. Christianity is very widespread, but that's largely because people who didn't accept Christianity were murdered hundreds of years ago. That doesn't make it any more likely that Jehovah is real. If there is something much more powerful than us somewhere out there, it probably won't resemble in any way the things described in the Bible. Why would they? The Bible was written by men who didn't have any magical source of knowledge about anything, any more than the ancient Greeks, or the ancient Norse, or the ancient Egyptians.

Lastly, if Jesus says to not lie than He Himself couldn't be a liar or else His sacrifice to forgive all sins (blindness to God) would be invalid. text:
@iriyabran
It was shot terribly and it constantly jumped from scene to scene. It was also incredibly boring. For a movie that was supposed to display the struggles of two people in love, it did a very lazy job of it. When it comes to the topic of homosexuality, I can think of a number of movies that are far, far better than Brokeback Mountain. No offence to you or your boyfriend, I just think it could have been so much more than it was.
author: kirikakirikakirika

text:
@kirikakirikakirika
I personally didn't feel bored while watching it. It covered lots of years of their life after all. Idk maybe it's just the effect of the entire movie industry nowdays that has made me more tolerant. Like for example Nolan movies. You can give this guy permission to make a 10h long movie and it will still feel unexplored and unfinished and yet painfully stale and boring. The only movie of his I genuinely enjoyed was The Prestige. The rest is just overhyped and overpraised. Even Inception got painfully boring during the snowy part. Anyway I do agree that some movies get a lot more attention than they deserve and some deserve more attention but seem to appeal to a minority. I am a huge fan of The Fountain which seems terribly underrated and the recent Cloud Atlas which I barely read anything about since people at that time were going crazy about popcorn superhero movies. And usually the excuse I hear about those movies are "oh shut up they're made for fun, we're just having fun" which implies that if a movie is made for fun it's somehow totally exempt from criticism and it's totally ok to spend millions of dollar for it while some people are actually trying to make movies with a soul and get shot down terribly.
author: iriyabran

text: @Kunta Kinte Oh hipster. I see that word thrown around so much I don't even know what it really mean. Cloud Atlas is by far not an average movie. Just the make up quality deserves a ton of acknowledgement. Superhero movies in general have been overdone for what, 12 years or more. It's gotten to a point where they don't even care to properly introduce the characters and their universe to the  audience which is not already part of the fanbase cause they're gonna make enough money off that fanbase anyway.Ofc he's gonna be critically acclaimed. There's nothing else to be acclaimed. International movies have been catching up fast and doing better.
author: iriyabran

text: @Kunta Kinte You might wanna reread my post but I'd rather not keep talking to a person who started throwing around the word hipster right off the bat. Also Nolan's Batman is not a sequel, it's a reboot.

author: Samuel Matos

text: Fredde, a British accent doesn't exist. Britain is comprised of 4 countries: England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland. And within each country, there are a variety of accents. So, which British accent exactly are you referring to? Just by saying he has a "British" accent you're basically confirming he can mimic many. You may not like or appreciate Gary Oldman, which is fine, but he does quite a few accents well.
author: Anne Beaudoin

text: @Clearly Anne i'm more thinking of the sterotypical accent you think of when thinking about brittain. like central london or something like that. Maybe you're brittish your self so you dont know  what i mean. But when you're foregin we kind of have a sterotypical brittish accent that you think of when you say someone has a brittish accent
author: Fredde

text: @Fredde I'm Canadian. And I understand that many people say "British" accent. But most people use the word British to mean English (from England), but it's not a synonym. You wouldn't say British to mean Scottish, Irish or Welsh normally. And unfortunately it shows one's ignorance (not YOU specifically, but everyone who uses the term). We don't know what we don't know, right? So I thought I'd mention it in case you were willing to learn something new. Many people would take offence since accents are actually very distinct. It's like telling a Canadian or Mexican they have an American accent. We are from the Americas, so we are American... but we're not from the United States (which calls itself and is known as America, which is a whole other topic of conversation). Just as if you (assuming you are from the U.S.) might be put off if you were told you have a Canadian accent because it's all part of the Americas, and it's all the same, right? You, too, might take offence. Maybe. And this note certainly is not meant to offend you in any way, just sharing a wider perspective on the subject. If you don't care... no worries. If it helps, then great.
author: Anne Beaudoin

text: @Clearly Anne yea, i dont really care, im gonna keep saying brittish accent
author: Fredde

text: @Clearly Anne I'm "British", from "Britain", you know, the place where "British" people live, and I don't care, and o don't think us "Brits" care! We come from Britain so we are British!
author: alikin0407

text: @alikin0407 I* don't think us "Brits" care!
author: alikin0407

text: @alikin0407  Haha... fair enough. I do know quite a few English people who do care.  I know because I've been corrected several times... hence the lesson I've learned. I guess some do... some don't.
author: Anne Beaudoin

text:
@Clearly Anne
 You just confirmed that when someone says British accent, you understand that they are referring to the stereotypical English accent. If that is the case then what was the point of your first comment stating that there are several accents used by the British and asking which he was referring to? I read your comments and understand the point you are trying to make but trying to make that point to a stranger on YouTube is ridiculously petty, especially when you immediately inform him that you understood what he was saying..

text: This segment is funny to me but I don't know how I feel about it. On one hand I hate twitter and I think the people that write this type of shit are very low people. On the other hand, the celebrities reading these tweets and laughing them off makes the celebrities come off as very arrogant like "HA! I dont care what you say about me, peasant. Don't you know who I am???" I'm not saying they should be at all emotionally affected but the way they do this just comes off to me a bit like the high and mighty celebrity looking down on the common folks. Also, showing these tweets on tv just validates the messed up people who write them and encourages more of that crap.
